ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learning about ceramics, archeology, and methods for making archeological inferences.
Hands-on experiences in pottery-making and pottery analysis

I gained hands-on experience and insights into how challenging ceramics are to make which gave me a good appreciation for the potters that we read about. I learned about methods of making ceramics, how to study whole ceramic pots from a collection, and how to study ceramic pastes from sherds.
We learned about ceramics from all over the world and how to analyze them, and we had hands-on experience making our own pot.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: prof. Underhill and TF Qi were really nice and responsive. Making a vessel was very valuable and useful for understanding the process of making pottery. Weaknesses: it was hard to engage with this course as a non-archeology major. Knowledge is sometimes assumed.

The hands-on nature of the class makes it very engaging. Having students lead the discussion every week is also a good way to maintain engagement in the reading materials. 

I would make sure students have a clear idea of their final paper as early as possible. Maybe ask for an outline and bibliography before the final paper to make sure students are on task.

The course was very conducive to student engagement and facilitated participation from everyone in a way that never felt daunting. However, some of the assignments and reports were overwhelming because of how much there was to get through and the time constraints for them. I think narrowing down the number of objects for analysis and providing a clear and more organized list of requirements and an option for work flow would be very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but only if you have a high interest in archeology.
Yes! It was the perfect combination of research and application.
Yes. This class is helpful for a variety of students:  art, archaeology, museum studies, religion, etc. It is very engaging, and you feel accomplished by the end of it.
I would definitely recommend the course to students looking for a fun social science credit with interest in art and pottery and in learning more about archaeology.
